learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate knowledge of relevant theories and conventions related to narrative structures.
Critically evaluate digital narratives in multimedia forms.
Produce short digital stories that effectively and affectively communicate intended messages.

assessments.task_description:
Select one digital story in any format. Write an essay of 1,500 words (+/- 10%, excluding the references list) that includes, in whatever order you feel is most appropriate:

  • An introductory paragraph, which outlines what will be discussed and includes a specific, argumentative thesis statement
  • A description of your selected story
  • Critical consideration of the message your story is trying to convey (i.e. its effect)
  • Critical consideration of how your story tries to convey that message (i.e. its affect)
  • An analysis of how your story’s effect and affect contribute to the audience's interpretation and experience of the story
  • A concluding paragraph, which summarises what has been discussed


All of these elements must come together to form a cohesive and compelling argument that relates to core course concepts. To recall these course concepts, refer to the titles of the course's lectures. You are being evaluated on (1) your knowledge of relevant concepts (namely effect and affect, as they are conceptualised in the course), theories, and conventions related to narrative structures presented in the course up until this point and (2) your ability to critically evaluate digital narratives in multimedia forms.

You should use the ‘I’ pronoun if doing so helps you more clearly express your ideas, but you are still expected to maintain an academic tone throughout your essay. If images help you articulate your ideas, you are welcome (but not required) to include them; if included, you must explicitly introduce, explain, and respond to these images in the body of your text, and they must include figure labels (e.g. ‘Figure 1’) and explanatory captions (neither included in the word count).

Your submission must include references to at least five academic sources. These references must be integrated through in-text citations, and must adhere to APA style.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

If you use AI to complete this assessment, you must include the name of the AI system(s) used and your entire chat history pertaining to the assessment in an appendix (not included in the word count).
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment will be submitted electronically via TurnItIn.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
In your regularly-scheduled tutorial, you will present your idea for your digital story (the final assessment) to a small group of your peers, and receive feedback on that idea. You will also provide feedback to your peers on their ideas for their digital stories.

Your presentation must be no longer than five minutes. You may use whatever materials (e.g. slides, drawings, notes) you wish to support your presentation. Your presentation will then be followed by a 10-minute question-and-answer (Q&A) period, where your peers will ask you to further explain your ideas, and will make suggestions for your how may improve these ideas in light of the final assessment's rubric. Following the presentation and Q&A (15 minutes total), your peers will provide written feedback to you, which you can then consider on your own time.

Specific instructions for this assessment will be provided in, and in advance of, the peer feedback tutorial.

This assessment is a hurdle. This means that if you do not complete this assessment, you will be unable to receive a passing grade for the course.

You will only receive a 'pass' for this assessment if you both present your own work and provide meaningful feedback to your peers. 'Meaningful' peer feedback means that your questions, comments, and suggestions are thoughtful, relevant, and constructive, and are provided via the correct online portal (link provided on Learn).

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Produce a digital story in a format of your choosing. Your digital story should be about the same topic/theme that you presented in the previous Peer Feedback Hurdle assessment; you must receive approval from a member of the teaching team if you wish to switch your topic/theme between the Peer Feedback Hurdle and Final Project.

The experience of your story must last at least two minutes. The story must contain at least two of these elements: text, graphics, animation, video, sound, narration, and/or interactive functionality. Your digital story must be accompanied by a brief text-based personal reflection of no more than 150 words. This reflection may summarise what is included in your story, note what inspired the story, and/or speak to your own experiences with the story-making process; it should also mention which key course concepts you are trying to evoke through your work. The reflection itself is not marked, but it will inform the marker's reception of your story. It is in essence an ‘artist's statement’ to contextualise your work.

Storytelling is a personal experience. For this assessment, your experiences and/or perspectives should be the focus of your story. Do not tell someone else’s story – tell your own.

You are being evaluated on your ability to produce a short digital story that effectively and affectively communicates an intended message. To do this, you will need to demonstrate knowledge of relevant concepts, theories, and conventions related to narrative structures. Your submission does not need to include any academic references, but must clearly speak to core course concepts. To recall these course concepts, refer to the titles of the course's lectures. This assessment will require you to self-sufficiently direct some of your own media training; recommendations for training opportunities will be made available on the course's Learn page.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

If you use AI to complete this assessment, you must include the name of the AI system(s) used and your entire chat history pertaining to the assessment in an appendix.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment will be submitted electronically via Blackboard. Before submitting any assessments for this course you must ensure you have completed UQ's compulsory online Academic Integrity Tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
